awd_titl_txt: Standard Grant: Forest Fuels: Equity, Environment, and Woody Biomass Energy Technologies in Michigan
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a collaborative research project that examines the socio-ecological implications of differently-scaled woody biomass energy technologies in Michigan, including residential woodstoves, community-scale boilers, and biomass power plants. The project will provide deeper understandings of the social acceptability of using wood for energy in Michigan. Having a more nuanced understanding of the cultural carrying capacity for woody biomass energy systems will help policy-makers determine which technologies may be appropriate for particular landscapes and communities. The results of this research are to be disseminated broadly though professional activities with Michigan's Statewide Wood Energy Team and the national Alliance for Green Heat, media outreach activities such as regional radio, and newspaper interviews. The project will also provide opportunities for training undergraduate students in historical and social science research methods, including the design and implementation of interviews, documentary analysis, focus groups, and surveys.

This collaborative research project will use new approaches for thinking about the relationship between renewable energy development and environmental justice. It combines spatial analysis with approaches from science and technology studies (STS) and environmental history to understand how these different technologies have distributed benefits and burdens since the late twentieth century. It will use multiple methods including archival analysis, semi-structured interviews, a survey, and spatial analyses, to investigate the sociopolitical factors that have led to adoption of biofuel technologies. By combining historical research, quantitative social science methods, and spatial analysis, this project will help to reveal how political and social dynamics from the past constrain technological development in the future. Researchers will communicate the results of the research through scholarly publications, public outreach efforts, and instructional activities in their classrooms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research analyzed the development of modern wood-burning energy technologies in Michigan since the energy crises of the 1970s. Our broad research aim was to examine how different scales and applications of woody biomass energy technologies—including residential woodstoves, community-scale boilers, and industrial power plants—have impacted social and ecological landscapes. The project combined spatial analysis with approaches from science and technology studies (STS), human dimensions of forestry, and environmental history to examine how technologies powered by wood have distributed socioecological benefits and burdens. Publications, presentations, and outreach activities created through this project were used to inform decision-making related to wood energy technologies. 

Specifically, we used a combination of semi-structured interviews, a state-wide survey, document analysis, and spatial tools to examine how different wood-burning applications have been shaped by different political dynamics and cultural identities. These methods also helped us explore how different systems of governance have shaped technological decision-making in the past, and how issues pertaining to procedural and distributive justice have played out in the implementation of woody biomass technologies in Michigan. Working in state and regional archives helped to reveal how energy and environmental politics have affected the development of forest-based fuel sources, while the state-wide survey was useful for measuring attitudes and perceptions about the adoption of wood-burning technologies. This research revealed nuanced ways in which the history of woody biomass energy technologies has influenced current perceptions about the sustainability of these technologies. 

Project findings were disseminated in five peer-reviewed publications, a book chapter, a dozen scholarly presentations, and several public talks. The project website outlines core lessons learned and includes mapping tools based upon the GIS database for this project. These interactive mapping tools help to illustrate different social and environmental factors related to wood-based bioenergy technologies in Michigan. Integrating the project website into Michigan State University and Northern Michigan University webpages makes these GIS-based technologies and mapping tools available to broader audiences. 

In total, this project has provided opportunities for training twelve undergraduate research assistants, ten of whom came from under-represented communities. The project also enhanced undergraduate courses at Northern Michigan University by providing opportunities for applied service-learning initiatives and contributed to the development of remote sensing curriculum at Michigan State University.

This project has had direct impacts on policy at the regional, state, national, and even international level. Results of this research were presented at the European Bioenergy Conference, which brought together international leaders, scholars, and private developers to think about how to develop new bioenergy technologies with greater attention to environmental justice. At the national level, the National Academy of Sciences invited project leaders to contribute to President Biden’s Executive Order Advancing Biotechnology and Biomanufacturing Innovation for a Sustainable, Safe, and Secure American Bioeconomy, 2023 (Section 3c). The Washington, D.C.-based Energy Futures Initiative invited project leaders to discuss bioenergy development and environmental justice as part of a forum that aimed to shape national energy policy. At the state level, a Michigan house representative and a state senator’s office reached out to project leaders to help inform legislation related to different types of bioenergy in Michigan. Project leaders also shared the results of this research at the meetings of the Michigan chapter of the Society of American Foresters.

In 2023, project leaders convened the Michigan Wood Energy Team for a state-wide workshop on the campus of Northern Michigan University. The goal of this workshop was to bring together key stakeholders involved in different aspects of Michigan’s wood-based bioeconomy, and to explore the past, present and future of wood energy in the region. We shared project results with a focus on questions of justice and sustainability in the context of bioenergy development. One of the key take-aways from that workshop was the potential to transition to wood heat for the campus of Northern Michigan University (NMU). This workshop helped lay the institutional foundations for a new initiative, known as the Northern Woodshed Project, that will examine the feasibility of using local wood resources at NMU’s Ripley Heating Plant. Guided by lessons learned from this project, the new initiative will not only examine economic and environmental feasibility, but the broader implications of a just and sustainable transition to a low-carbon economy.
